div.l: Out of þe dore he goth ful pⁱriuely
Whan þat he saugh his tyme softely
He lokeþ vp and down til he hath fonde
The Clerkes hors þ̉er as it stode y boıı̄unde
Bi hynde the Mille vnder a leuesel
And to þis hors he goth him faire ⁊and wel
He strepith of þe bridel right a noon
And whan þe hors was laus he gynneþ gon
Toward þe fen þare wilde mares renne
And forth wit wehe þoruȝ þikke and þoruȝ þenne
This Mellere goth agayn no worde he seyde
But doþ his note and wit his clerkes pleide
Til þat hire corn was faire ⁊and wel y gᵒrounde
And whan the mele is sakked and y bounde
This Iohn goth out ⁊and fynt his hors a way
And gan to crye harrow and weyleaway
Oure hors is lost Aleyn for goddes banes
Steppe on þi fete come of Man al at anes
Allas oure wardeyn has his palfray lorn
This Aleyn al for gate boþe mele ⁊and corn
Al was out of his mynde his housbondrie
What whilk way is he gon he gan to crye
The wif come lepinge Inward at a ren
She seide allas youre hors goþ to þe fen
Wit wilde mares as faste as he may goo
Vnthank come on his honde þat bonde him soo
And he þat better sholde haue knyt þe reyne
Allas qduod Iohn Aleyn for cristes peyne
Ley doun þi swerd and I wil myn alswa
I is ful swift god wate as is a ra
Bi goddes hert he sall nouȝ scape vs baþe
Whi ne hadde þᵘou put þe capil in þe lathe
Il haille bi god Aleyn þow is a fonne
Thise sely Clerkes han ful faste y ronne
Toward þe fen bothen Aleyn ⁊and eke Iohn
And whan the Mellere seigh þat þei were go
He half a busshel of here flour haþ take
And bad his wif go knede it in A Cake
And seide I trowe þe Clerkes weren aferd
Yet can a Meller make a Clerkes berd
For al his art yet lat hem gon hir wey
